HTMLInputElement.summary: The HTMLInputElement interface provides special properties and methods for manipulating the options, layout, and presentation of input elements.

remarks.para: -HTML element implementing this interface: input

HTMLInputElementAccept.summary: The accept property of the interface reflects the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element's accept attribute, generally a comma-separated list of unique file type specifiers providing a hint for the expected file type for an <input> of type file. If the attribute is not explicitly set, the accept property is an empty string.

remarks.para:
-
-
-
-File type specifiers
-Using files from web applications
-File API

HTMLInputElementAccept.value: A string representing the element's accept value or an empty string if no accept is explicitly set.

HTMLInputElementAlt.summary: The alt property of the interface defines the textual label for the button for users and user agents who cannot use the image. It reflects the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's alt attribute.

remarks.para: The alt property is valid for the image type only. It should be a non-empty string giving the label that would be appropriate for an equivalent button if the image was unavailable.

-
-
-button
-input
-img
-Good alt text, bad alt text â€” Making your content perceivable on WCAG.com (2021)
-An alt Decision Tree on W3C Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI)

HTMLInputElementAutocomplete.summary: The autocomplete property of the interface indicates whether the value of the control can be automatically completed by the browser. It reflects the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's autocomplete attribute.

remarks.para:
-input
-
-HTML autocomplete attribute
-ARIA aria-autocomplete attribute
-Turning off autocompletion

HTMLInputElementAutocomplete.value: A string; the value of the autocomplete attribute ("on", "off", a <token-list>), or the empty string "" if unspecified.

HTMLInputElementCancel.summary: The cancel event fires on an input element when the user cancels the file picker dialog via the <kbd>Esc</kbd> key or the cancel button and when the user re-selects the same files that were previously selected of type="file".

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable but can bubble.
-HTML input element

HTMLInputElementCapture.summary: The capture property of the interface reflects the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element's capture attribute. Only relevant to the <input> of type file, the property and attribute specify whether, a new file should be captured from a user-facing (user) or outward facing (environment) camera or microphone. The type of file is defined the accept attribute. If the attribute is not explicitly set, the capture property is an empty string.

remarks.para:
-
-
-
-
-File type specifiers
-Using files from web applications
-File API

HTMLInputElementCapture.value: A string; Generally either user or environment, or an empty string ("").

HTMLInputElementChecked.summary: The checked property of the interface specifies the current checkedness of the element; that is, whether the form control is checked or not.

remarks.para: The boolean checked property is relevant to the radio (<input type="radio">) and checkbox (<input type="checkbox">) input types.

The presence of the HTML checked attribute indicates the checkbox is checked by default. It does not indicate whether this checkbox is currently checked: if the checkbox's state is changed, this content attribute does not reflect the change; only the HTMLInputElement's checked IDL property is updated. The checked attribute is reflected by the property.

When a radio input checked property is true, all other radio inputs with the same are false. If any radio button in a same-named group of radio buttons is , as long as one button in the group is checked, the object's read-only property for each radio button in the group will be false.
A checkbox's value is only included in the submitted data upon form submission if checked is true. The value of the property has no effect on a checkbox's checked value.

-input
-
-:checked pseudo-class

HTMLInputElementCheckValidity.summary: The checkValidity() method of the interface returns a boolean value which indicates if the element meets any constraint validation rules applied to it. If false, the method also fires an event on the element. Because there's no default browser behavior for checkValidity(), canceling this invalid event has no effect.

blockquote.para: An HTML {{htmlelement("input")}} element with a non-null is considered invalid, will match the CSS {{cssxref(":invalid")}} pseudo-class, and will cause checkValidity() to return false. Use the method to set the to the empty string to set the state to be valid.

remarks.para:
-
-input
-form
-Learn: Client-side form validation
-Guide: Constraint validation
-CSS :valid and :invalid pseudo-classes

HTMLInputElementCheckValidity.returns: Returns true if the element's value has no validity problems; otherwise, returns false.

HTMLInputElementDefaultChecked.summary: The defaultChecked property of the interface specifies the default checkedness state of the element. This property reflects the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's checked attribute.

remarks.para: The boolean checked attribute is valid for the radio (<input type="radio">) and checkbox (<input type="checkbox">) input types. The presence of the attribute sets the defaultChecked property to true.

-input
-:default pseudo-class
-:checked pseudo-class

HTMLInputElementDefaultValue.summary: The defaultValue property of the interface indicates the original (or default) value of the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element. It reflects the element's value attribute.
HTMLInputElementDefaultValue.value: A string representing the default, or original, value of the <input> element.

HTMLInputElementDirName.summary: The dirName property of the interface is the directionality of the element and enables the submission of that value. It reflects the value of the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's dirName attribute. This property can be retrieved or set.

remarks.para: Valid only for hidden, text, search, url, tel, and email <input> types, the dirname attribute controls how the element's directionality is submitted. When included, the form control will submit with two name/value pairs: the first being the name and value, and the second being the value of the dirname attribute as the name, with a value of ltr or rtl as set by the browser.

-
-dir attribute
-Sending form data

HTMLInputElementDirName.value: A string. The direction of the element.

HTMLInputElementDisabled.summary: The HTMLInputElement.disabled property is a boolean value that reflects the disabled HTML attribute, which indicates whether the control is disabled. If it is disabled, it does not accept clicks. A disabled element is unusable and un-clickable.

HTMLInputElementFiles.summary: The HTMLInputElement.files property allows you to access the selected with the <input type="file"> element.
HTMLInputElementFiles.value: A object listing the selected files, if any, or null if the HTMLInputElement is not of type="file".

HTMLInputElementForm.summary: The form read-only property of the interface returns an object that owns this {{HTMLElement("input")}}, or null if this input is not owned by any form.

remarks.para:
-
-
-input
-HTML form attribute
-HTML forms guide

HTMLInputElementFormAction.summary: The formAction property of the interface is the URL of the program that is executed on the server when the form that owns this control is submitted. It reflects the value of the <input>'s formaction attribute.

remarks.para: This property is valid only for submit and image <input> elements.
Its value overrides the property of the interface if the form is submitted via the input. This property can be retrieved or set.

-
-
-
-
-<input type="submit">
-<input type="image">
-Sending form data

HTMLInputElementFormAction.value: A string. The URL for form submission.

HTMLInputElementFormEnctype.summary: The formEnctype property of the interface is the {{Glossary("MIME_type", "MIME type")}} of the content sent to the server when the <input> with the formEnctype is the method of form submission. It reflects the value of the <input>'s formenctype attribute.

remarks.para: This property is valid only for submit and image <input> elements.
Its value overrides the property of the interface if the form is submitted via the input. This property can be retrieved or set. If not set, the value is the empty string ("").

-
-
-
-
-
-<input type="submit">
-<input type="image">
-Sending form data

HTMLInputElementFormMethod.summary: The formMethod property of the interface is the {{Glossary("HTTP")}} method used to submit the {{HtmlElement("form")}} if the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element is the control that submits the form. It reflects the value of the <input>'s formmethod attribute.

remarks.para: This property is valid only for submit and image <input> elements.

The value overrides the property of the interface if the form is submitted via the input. This property can be retrieved or set. If set with an empty or invalid value, the invalid default value is "get". If not set at all, the value is the empty string ("").

-
-
-
-
-
-<input type="submit">
-<input type="image">
-Sending form data

HTMLInputElementFormNoValidate.summary: The formNoValidate property of the interface is a boolean value indicating if the {{htmlelement("form")}} will bypass constraint validation when submitted via the input. It reflects the <input> element's formnovalidate attribute.

remarks.para: This property is valid only for submit and image <input> elements.
Its value overrides the property of the interface if the form is submitted via the input. This property can be retrieved or set.

-
-
-
-
-
-
-<input type="submit">
-<input type="image">
-form
-
-
-Learn: Client-side form validation
-Guide: Constraint validation

HTMLInputElementFormTarget.summary: The formTarget property of the interface is the tab, window, or iframe where the response of the submitted {{HtmlElement("form")}} is to be displayed. It reflects the value of the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element's formtarget attribute.

remarks.para: This property is valid only for submit and image <input> elements.
Its value overrides the property of the interface if the form is submitted via the input. This property can be retrieved or set. If not set, the value is the empty string ("").

-
-
-
-
-
-<input type="submit">
-<input type="image">
-Sending form data

HTMLInputElementHeight.summary: The height property of the interface specifies the height of a control. It reflects the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's height attribute.

remarks.para: The height property is valid for the image type only. It defines the vertical dimension of the image button, in pixels. If CSS sizing properties apply to the control, the value is the height of the content box of the rendered control, not the value of the height attribute. If no height is set and CSS does not impact the control's size, the height will be the intrinsic height of the image. If the image didn't load, the value will be the height of the alt text. The height will be 0 if the height is not known; if no height is set, CSS doesn't impact the height, the image didn't load, and either the value of the is the empty string or no src is set.

-
-
-
-
-button
-input
-img
-CSS inline-size property
-CSS height property
-CSS aspect-ratio property
-CSS box sizing module

HTMLInputElementIndeterminate.summary: The indeterminate property of the interface returns a boolean value that indicates whether the checkbox is in the indeterminate state. For example, a "select all/deselect all" checkbox may be in the indeterminate state when some but not all of its sub-controls are checked. The indeterminate state can only be set via JavaScript and is only relevant to checkbox controls.

remarks.para: It is unrelated to the property, and an indeterminate checkbox can be either checked or unchecked. Being indeterminate only affects the checkbox's appearance (see example below), not its presence when submitted (which is controlled by the checkedness).

-
-
-input
-Indeterminate state checkboxes
-CSS :indeterminate property

HTMLInputElementInvalid.summary: The invalid event fires when a submittable element has been checked for validity and doesn't satisfy its constraints.

remarks.para: This event can be useful for displaying a summary of the problems with a form on submission. When a form is submitted, invalid events are fired at each form control that is invalid. The validity of submittable elements is checked before submitting their owner form, or after the checkValidity() method of the element or its owner <form> is called.
It is not checked on .

-HTML form element
-Related event:
-CSS :invalid pseudo class

HTMLInputElementLabels.summary:
The HTMLInputElement.labels read-only property returns a
of the {{HTMLElement("label")}} elements associated with the
input element, if the element is not hidden. If the element has the
type hidden, the property returns null.
HTMLInputElementLabels.value:
A containing the <label> elements associated
with the <input> element.

HTMLInputElementList.summary: The list read-only property of the interface returns the pointed to by the list attribute of the element, or null if the list attribute is not defined or the list attribute's value is not associated with any <datalist> in the same tree.

blockquote.para: This is a read-only property. To associate a <datalist> with an element, set the value of the list attribute with .

remarks.para:
-
-
-
-
-
-input
-datalist
-option

HTMLInputElementMax.summary: The max property of the interface reflects the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element's max attribute, which generally defines the maximum valid value for a numeric or date-time input. If the attribute is not explicitly set, the max property is an empty string.

remarks.para:
-input of type input/range, input/number, input/date, input/month, input/week, and input/time
-
-
-

HTMLInputElementMax.value: A string representing the element's max value or an empty string if no max is explicitly set.

HTMLInputElementMaxLength.summary: The maxLength property of the interface indicates the maximum number of characters (in {{glossary("UTF-16", "UTF-16 code units")}}) allowed to be entered for the value of the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element, and the maximum number of characters allowed for the value to be valid. It reflects the element's maxlength attribute. -1 means there is no limit on the length of the value.

blockquote.para: Browser generally prevent users from entering more characters than the maxlength attribute allows. Should the length be longer, the element is considered invalid and the object's property will be true.

HTMLInputElementMaxLength.value: A number representing the element's maxlength if present, or -1.

HTMLInputElementMin.summary: The min property of the interface reflects the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element's min attribute, which generally defines the minimum valid value for a numeric or date-time input. If the attribute is not explicitly set, the min property is an empty string.

remarks.para:
-input of type input/range, input/number, input/date, input/month, input/week, and input/time
-
-
-

HTMLInputElementMin.value: A string representing the element's min value or an empty string if no min is explicitly set.

HTMLInputElementMinLength.summary: The minLength property of the interface indicates the minimum number of characters (in {{glossary("UTF-16", "UTF-16 code units")}}) required for the value of the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element to be valid. It reflects the element's minlength attribute. -1 means there is no minimum length requirement.

blockquote.para: If the input has a value, and that value has fewer characters than the minlength attribute requires, the element is considered invalid and the object's property will be true.

HTMLInputElementMinLength.value: A number representing the element's minlength if present or -1.

HTMLInputElementMultiple.summary: The HTMLInputElement.multiple property indicates if an input can have more than one value. Firefox currently only supports multiple for <input type="file">.

remarks.para:
-FileList
-Bug 523771 - Support <input type=file multiple>

HTMLInputElementName.summary: The name property of the interface indicates the name of the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element. It reflects the element's name attribute.
HTMLInputElementName.value: A string representing the element's name.

HTMLInputElementPattern.summary: The pattern property of the interface represents a regular expression a non-null input value should match. It reflects the input element's pattern attribute.

remarks.para: The pattern property is valid for text, search, url, tel, email, and password types. It defines a regular expression that the input's must match in order for the value to pass constraint validation.
If a non-null value doesn't conform to the constraints set by the pattern value, the object's read-only property will be true.

-input
-
-Client-side validation
-:valid and :invalid pseudo-classes

HTMLInputElementPlaceholder.summary: The placeholder property of the interface represents a hint to the user of what can be entered in the control. It reflects the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's placeholder attribute.

remarks.para:
-input
-
-{{cssxref("::placeholder")}} pseudo-element
-:placeholder-shown pseudo-class

HTMLInputElementPopoverTargetAction.summary: The popoverTargetAction property of the interface gets and sets the action to be performed ("hide", "show", or "toggle") on a popover element being controlled by an input element of type="button".

remarks.para: It reflects the value of the popovertargetaction HTML attribute.

-popover HTML global attribute
-Popover API

HTMLInputElementPopoverTargetAction.value: An enumerated value. Possible values are:

HTMLInputElementPopoverTargetElement.summary: The popoverTargetElement property of the interface gets and sets the popover element to control via an {{htmlelement("input")}} element of type="button".

remarks.para: It is the JavaScript equivalent of the popovertarget HTML attribute.
Establishing a relationship between a popover and its invoker button using the popoverTargetElement property has two additional useful effects:

-popover HTML global attribute
-Popover API

HTMLInputElementPopoverTargetElement.value: A reference to a popover element in the DOM.

HTMLInputElementReadOnly.summary: The readOnly property of the interface indicates that the user cannot modify the value of the {{htmlelement("input")}}. It reflects the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's readonly boolean attribute; returning true if the attribute is present and false when omitted.

remarks.para: Unlike a form control with a true property, a true readOnly property value does not prevent the user from clicking or selecting in the control.

While the HTML readonly attribute is ignored if the type is hidden, range, color, checkbox, radio, file, submit, reset, button, and image, the readOnly property is true for these input types if the attribute is present, false otherwise.

-input
-
-:read-only pseudo-class

HTMLInputElementReportValidity.summary: The reportValidity() method of the interface performs the same validity checking steps as the method. In addition, if the event is not canceled, the browser displays the problem to the user.

remarks.para:
-
-input
-form
-Learn: Client-side form validation
-Guide: Constraint validation
-CSS :valid and :invalid pseudo-classes

HTMLInputElementReportValidity.returns: Returns true if the element's value has no validity problems; otherwise, returns false.

HTMLInputElementRequired.summary: The required property of the interface specifies that the user must fill in a value before submitting a form. It reflects the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's required attribute.

remarks.para: While the HTML boolean required attribute is ignored if the type is hidden, range, color, submit, reset, button, and image, the required property is true for these input types if the attribute is present, false otherwise.
If a required input doesn't have a value, the object's read-only property will be true.

-input
-
-:required pseudo-class

HTMLInputElementSearch.summary: CAUTION Non-standard The search event is fired when a search is initiated using an input element of type="search".

remarks.para: There are several ways a search can be initiated, such as by pressing <kbd>Enter</kbd> while the input is focused, or, if the incremental attribute is present, after a UA-defined timeout elapses since the most recent keystroke (with new keystrokes resetting the timeout so the firing of the event is debounce).

Current UA implementations of <input type="search"> have an additional control to clear the field. Using this control also fires the search event. In that case the value of the input element will be the empty string.
This event is not cancelable.

HTMLInputElementSelect.summary:
The HTMLInputElement.select() method selects all the text
in a textarea element or in an input element
that includes a text field.

remarks.para:
-input
-textarea
-
-

HTMLInputElementSelectionchange.summary:
The selectionchange event of the Selection API is fired when the text selection within an input element is changed.
This includes both changes in the selected range of characters, or if the caret moves.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable.
The event is usually processed by adding an event listener on the {{HTMLElement("input")}}, and in the handler function read by the selectionStart, selectionEnd and selectionDirection properties.
It is also possible to add a listener on the onselectionchange event handler, and within the handler function use to get the . However this is not very useful for getting changes to text selections.

HTMLInputElementSelectionDirection.summary: The selectionDirection property of the interface is a string that indicates the direction in which the user is selecting the text.

remarks.para:
- property
- property
- property
- method

HTMLInputElementSelectionDirection.value:
A string. It can have one of the following values:
NOTEOn Windows, the direction indicates the position of the caret relative to the selection: a "forward" selection has the caret at the end of the selection and a "backward" selection has the caret at the start of the selection. Windows has no "none" direction.
NOTEOn Mac, the direction indicates which end of the selection is affected when the user adjusts the size of the selection using the arrow keys with the Shift modifier: the "forward" direction means the end of the selection is modified, and the "backward" direction means the start of the selection is modified. The "none" direction is the default on Mac, it indicates that no particular direction has yet been selected. The user sets the direction implicitly when first adjusting the selection, based on which directional arrow key was used.

HTMLInputElementSelectionEnd.summary: The selectionEnd property of the interface is a number that represents the end index of the selected text. When there is no selection, this returns the offset of the character immediately following the current text input cursor position.

blockquote.para: According to the WHATWG forms spec selectionEnd property applies only to inputs of types text, search, URL, tel, and password. In modern browsers, throws an exception while setting selectionEnd property on the rest of input types. Additionally, this property returns null while accessing selectionEnd property on non-text input elements.

remarks.para:
If selectionEnd is less than selectionStart, then both are
treated as the value of selectionEnd.

- property
- property
- method

HTMLInputElementSelectionStart.summary: The selectionStart property of the interface is a number that represents the beginning index of the selected text. When nothing is selected, then returns the position of the text input cursor (caret) inside of the <input> element.

blockquote.para: According to the WHATWG forms spec selectionStart property applies only to inputs of types text, search, URL, tel, and password. In modern browsers, throws an exception while setting selectionStart property on the rest of input types. Additionally, this property returns null while accessing selectionStart property on non-text input elements.

remarks.para:
If selectionStart is greater than selectionEnd, then both are
treated as the value of selectionEnd.

- property
- property
- method

HTMLInputElementSelect.summary: The select event fires when some text has been selected.

HTMLInputElementSetCustomValidity.summary: The HTMLInputElement.setCustomValidity() method sets a custom validity message for the element.

remarks.para:
-Learn: Client-side form validation
-Guide: Constraint validation
-

HTMLInputElementSetRangeText.summary:
The HTMLInputElement.setRangeText() method replaces a
range of text in an input or textarea element with
a new string.

remarks.para:
-input
-textarea
-
-

HTMLInputElementSetSelectionRange.summary: The HTMLInputElement.setSelectionRange() method sets the start and end positions of the current text selection in an input or textarea element.

remarks.para: The element must be focused for the call to have any effect.

Optionally, you can specify the direction in which selection should be considered to have occurred. This lets you indicate, for example, that the selection was set by the user clicking and dragging from the end of the selected text toward the beginning.
This method updates the , , and properties in one call.
The element must be of one of the following input types: password, search, tel, text, or url. Otherwise the browser throws an InvalidStateError exception.
If you wish to select all text of an input element, you can use the HTMLInputElement.select() method instead.

-input
-textarea
-
-

HTMLInputElementShowPicker.summary: The HTMLInputElement.showPicker() method displays the browser picker for an input element.

remarks.para: This is the same picker that would normally be displayed when the element is selected, but can be triggered from a button press or other user interaction.

Commonly browsers implement it for inputs of these types: "date", "month", "week", "time", "datetime-local", "color", or "file".
It can also be prepopulated with items from a datalist element or autocomplete attribute.
More generally, this method should ideally display the picker for any input element on the platform that has a picker.

-input
-
-
-datalist
-autocomplete

HTMLInputElementSize.summary: The size property of the interface defines the number of visible characters displayed. It reflects the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's size attribute.

remarks.para: The size property is relevant to the text, search, tel, email, url, and password input type only. The value is a non-negative integer greater than zero. If omitted or invalid, the value is 20.

HTMLInputElementSrc.summary: The src property of the interface specifies the source of an image to display as the graphical submit button. It reflects the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's src attribute.

remarks.para: The src property is valid for the image type only.

-
-button
-input
-img

HTMLInputElementStep.summary: The step property of the interface indicates the step by which numeric or date-time {{HTMLElement("input")}} elements can change. It reflects the element's step attribute. Valid values include the string "any" or a string containing a positive floating point number. If the attribute is not explicitly set, the step property is an empty string.

remarks.para:
-input of type input/range, input/number, input/date, input/month, input/week, and input/time
-
-

HTMLInputElementStep.value: A string representing the element's step value or an empty string if no step is explicitly set.

HTMLInputElementStepDown.summary:
The
HTMLInputElement.stepDown() method decrements the
value of a numeric type of input element by the value of the
step attribute or up
to n multiples of the step attribute if a number is passed as the
parameter.

remarks.para:
The method, when invoked, decrements the
value by (step * n), where n
defaults to 1 if not specified, and
step defaults to the
default value for step if not specified.

Valid on all numeric, date, and time input types that support the step attribute,
including input/date, input/month,
input/week, input/time,
input/datetime-local,
input/number, and input/range.

Given <input id="myTime" type="time" max="17:00" step="900" value="17:00">,
invoking myTime.stepDown(3) will change the value to 16:15, decrementing the
time by 3 * 900, or 45 minutes. myTime.stepDown(), with no
parameter, would have resulted in 16:45, as n defaults to
1.

However, calling stepDown on <input type="time" max="17:00" step="900"> would not set the value to 17:00, as one would expect â€” and as it does for stepUp when the input is <input type="time" min="17:00" step="900">. Instead, the first call to stepDown will set the initial value to 23:45 even though the max attribute is set. The second call will set the value to 17:00. And the third call to will set the value to 16:45.

The method, when invoked, changes the form control's value by the value given in the
step attribute, multiplied by the parameter, within the constraints set
within the form control. The default value for the parameter, if not is passed, is 1.
The method will not cause the value to go below the
min value set or defy the
constraints set by the
step attribute. A
negative value for n will increment the value, but will not increment
beyond the max value.

If the value before invoking the stepDown() method is invalid, for
example, if it doesn't match the constraints set by the step attribute,
invoking the stepDown() method will return a value that does match the form
controls constraints.

If the form control is non time, date, or numeric in nature, and therefore does not
support the step attribute (see the list of supported input types above), or if the step value is set to any, an
InvalidStateError exception is thrown.

-input
-
-
-step,
min and
max attributes

HTMLInputElementStepUp.summary:
The HTMLInputElement.stepUp() method increments the value
of a numeric type of input element by the value of the
step attribute, or the
default step value if the step attribute is not explicitly set. The method,
when invoked, increments the value by
(step * n), where n defaults to
1 if not specified, and
step defaults to the
default value for step if not specified.

remarks.para:
The method, when invoked, changes the form control's value by the value given in the
step attribute, multiplied by the parameter, within the constraints set on
the form control. The default value for the parameter, if no value is passed, is
1. The method will not cause the value to exceed the
set max value, or defy
the constraints set by the
step attribute.

If the value before invoking the stepUp() method is invalidâ€”for example,
if it doesn't match the constraints set by the step attributeâ€”invoking the
stepUp() method will return a value that does match the form controls
constraints.

If the form control is non time, date, or numeric in nature, and therefore does not
support the step attribute (see the list of supported input types in the
table above), or if the step value is set to any, an
InvalidStateError exception is thrown.

-input
-
-
-step,
min and
max attributes

HTMLInputElementType.summary: The type property of the interface indicates the kind of data allowed in the {{HTMLElement("input")}} element, for example a number, a date, or an email. Browsers will select the appropriate widget and behavior to help users to enter a valid value.

remarks.para: It reflects the type attribute of the input element.

- property
- property

HTMLInputElementType.value: A string representing the type.Its possible values are listed in the attribute's input types section.

HTMLInputElementValidationMessage.summary: The validationMessage read-only property of the interface returns a string representing a localized message that describes the validation constraints that the {{htmlelement("input")}} control does not satisfy (if any).

remarks.para: If the <input> element is not a candidate for constraint validation ( is false), or it satisfies its constraints, the value is the empty string ("").

If the element is a candidate for constraint validation (willValidate is true) and the constraints are not met (the object's valid property is false), the value is the error message that would be shown to the user during validation.

-input
-
-
-
-
-
-
-Learn: Client-side form validation
-Guide: Constraint validation
-CSS :valid and :invalid pseudo-classes

HTMLInputElementValidity.summary: The validity read-only property of the interface returns a object that represents the validity states this element is in.

remarks.para:
-
-input
-form
-Learn: Client-side form validation
-Guide: Constraint validation

HTMLInputElementValue.summary: The value property of the interface represents the current value of the {{htmlelement("input")}} element as a string.

remarks.para: This property can also be set directly, for example to set a default value based on some condition.

-input
-
-

HTMLInputElementValue.value: A string specifying the default value of the input element.

HTMLInputElementValueAsDate.summary: The valueAsDate property of the interface represents the current value of the {{htmlelement("input")}} element as a {{jsxref("Date")}}, or null if conversion is not possible.

remarks.para: This property can also be set directly, for example to set a default date based on some condition. If the provided value is neither null nor a Date object, a is thrown. If the provided value is null or an invalid date, the input value is set to the empty string.
This property always returns null when accessed on an input that isn't date- or time-based. When setting this property on such an input, an InvalidStateError is thrown.

-input
-
-

HTMLInputElementValueAsDate.value: A object or null if a conversion is impossible. The date returned should always be interpreted as a UTC timeâ€”for example, using methods like getUTCDate() instead of getDate(). If you are not careful, the result may be off by 1â€”for example, if the user lives in a negative UTC offset (the US, for example), then interpreting the date as a local date will result in the previous day from what the user selected.The month, date, and week input types return a UTC date that represents the first instant of the inputted time spanâ€”that is, they are always midnight in UTC. For month, the date is the first day of the month. For week, the date is the Monday of the week. The time input type always has the date set to 1970-01-01.The datetime-local input type does not support the valueAsDate property, because it represents a date and time in the local time zone (a wall clock time), but Date objects represent an absolute point in time. However, some browsers may provide a non-standard implementation. WHATWG is working on integrating the API with the date/time inputs to account for this use case.

HTMLInputElementValueAsNumber.summary: The valueAsNumber property of the interface represents the current value of the {{htmlelement("input")}} element as a number or NaN if converting to a numeric value is not possible.

remarks.para: This property can also be set directly, for example to set a default numeric value based on some condition.

-input
-
-

HTMLInputElementValueAsNumber.value: A number that represents the value of the element or NaN if numeric conversion is impossible.

HTMLInputElementWebkitdirectory.summary: The webkitdirectory property of the interface reflects the webkitdirectory HTML attribute, which indicates that <input type="file"> elements should let the user select directories instead of files.

remarks.para:
When a directory is selected, the directory and its entire hierarchy of contents are included in the set of selected items.
The selected file system entries can be obtained using the property.

blockquote.para:
This property is called webkitdirectory in the specification due to its origins as a Google Chrome-specific API.
It's likely to be renamed someday.

remarks.para:
-File and Directory Entries API
-
-

HTMLInputElementWebkitdirectory.value: A Boolean; true if the input element should allow picking only directories or false if only files should be selectable.

HTMLInputElementWebkitEntries.summary:
The read-only webkitEntries
property of the interface contains an array of file
system entries (as objects based on ) representing files
and/or directories selected by the user using an input element of
type file, but only if that selection was made using drag-and-drop:
selecting a file in the dialog will leave the property empty.

remarks.para:
The array can only contain directories if the
property is
true. This means the <input> element was configured to
let the user choose directories.

blockquote.para:
This property is called webkitEntries in the specification due to its
origins as a Google Chrome-specific API. It's likely to be renamed someday.

remarks.para:
-File and Directory Entries API
-
-
-

HTMLInputElementWebkitEntries.value:
An array of objects based on , each representing one file
which is selected in the input element. More specifically, files are
represented by objects, and, if they're allowed,
directories are represented by objects.

HTMLInputElementWidth.summary: The width property of the interface specifies the width of a control. It reflects the {{htmlelement("input")}} element's width attribute.

remarks.para: The width property is valid for the image type only. It defines the preferred horizontal size of the image button, in pixels. The property value is the width of the content-box of the rendered button. CSS box model properties impacting the size of the control take precedence.

If no width is set and no CSS width properties impact the control, the width will be the intrinsic width of the image. If the image didn't load, the value will be the maximum intrinsic width of the alt text. The width will be 0 if the width is not known; if no width is set, no CSS dimensions apply, no image loaded, and either the value of the is the empty string or no src is set.

-
-
-
-
-button
-input
-img
-CSS inline-size property
-CSS width property
-CSS aspect-ratio property
-CSS box sizing module

HTMLInputElementWillValidate.summary: The willValidate read-only property of the interface indicates whether the {{htmlelement("input")}} element is a candidate for constraint validation. It is false if any conditions bar it from constraint validation, including:

remarks.para:
-
-input
-form
-Learn: Client-side form validation
-Guide: Constraint validation
